abstract.text: Use a scene-based life cycle in SwiftUI while keeping your existing codebase.

metadata.title: Migrating to the SwiftUI life cycle

inlineContent.text: Take advantage of the declarative syntax in SwiftUI and its compatibility with spatial frameworks by moving your app to the SwiftUI life cycle.

Moving to the SwiftUI life cycle requires several steps, including changing your app’s entry point, configuring the launch of your app, and monitoring life-cycle changes with the methods that SwiftUI provides.
The

For more information on

To indicate the entry of a SwiftUI app, you’ll need to create a new file that defines your app’s structure.
Open your project in Xcode.
Choose File > New > File > Swift file.

inlineContent.text: If you’re migrating an app that contains storyboards to SwiftUI, make sure to remove them when they’re no longer needed.
Open your project in Xcode.
Remove
from the project navigator.
Choose your app’s target.
Open the
file.

Remove the

dictionary.
This figure shows the structure of the
file before removing these keys.
The scene delegate continues to be called after removing the keys from the
file, so you can still handle other scene-based life cycle changes in this file.
If you were previously launching your app in your scene delegate, remove the
method from your scene delegate.
If you didn’t previously support scenes in your app and rely on your app delegate to respond to the launch of your app, ensure you’re no longer setting a root view controller in
Instead, return
You will no longer be able to monitor life-cycle changes in your app delegate due to the scene-based nature of SwiftUI (see
Prefer to handle these changes in
, the life cycle enumeration that SwiftUI provides to monitor the phases of a scene.
Observe the
value to initiate actions when the phase changes.
Interpret the value differently based on where you read it from.
If you read the phase from inside a
instance, the value reflects the phase of the scene that contains the view.
If you read the phase from within an
instance, the value reflects an aggregation of the phases of all of the scenes in your app.
To handle scene-based events with a scene delegate, provide your scene delegate to your SwiftUI app inside your app delegate.

abstract.text: A property wrapper that reads a value from a view’s environment.
A property wrapper type that you use to create an AppKit app delegate.
A part of an app’s user interface with a life cycle managed by the
system.
An indication of a scene’s operational state.
A property wrapper type that you use to create a UIKit app delegate.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides
modifiers that you use to configure views.
A property wrapper that is used in
to provide a delegate from
WatchKit.
The information about the app’s scene-based life-cycle support.
The default configuration details the system uses to create new scenes.
Configurations for scenes you use to display content on the device’s main screen and respond to user interactions.
The name of the storyboard file containing the scene’s initial user interface.
The name of the app’s main storyboard file.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A set of methods to manage shared behaviors for your app.
Tells the delegate that the launch process is almost done and the app is almost ready to run.
Tells the delegate about the addition of a scene to the app.
Respond to system notifications when your app is in the foreground or background, and handle other significant system-related events.
Create a shared codebase to build a multiplatform app that offers widgets and an App Clip.
